Award.AwardTitle: Mentor-Connect: Leadership Development and Outreach for ATE-2

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advanced technological education programs in community colleges are facing the same challenges created by retirements and the need for knowledge transfer and leadership development as their business and industry partners. The Mentor-Connect project addresses these challenges by having current and experienced project leaders in the Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Program serve as mentors and develop systematic mentoring services for new and prospective ATE grantees to develop the next generation of leaders in advanced technological education and achieve broader impacts for the National Science Foundation (NSF) ATE program. Ultimately, advanced technological education programs and the industries they partner with will be impacted and improved across the United States.

Florence-Darlington Technical College, in partnership with the American Association of Community Colleges (AACC), will create, implement, and evaluate a regenerative mentoring system for leadership development and knowledge transfer designed to broaden the impact of the ATE Program. The project will be guided by personnel involved with the award-winning IBM Corporation Global Mentoring Program, and it will leverage talent within the ATE project community to meet a common and growing challenge: knowledge transfer to prepare the next generation of STEM faculty leaders. Additionally, the project will support: 1) an increase in engagement with and competitive proposals from colleges and populations underrepresented in the ATE program, 2) technical assistance and online resources for use both by mentors and prospective and current Principal Investigators (PIs), 3) expansion and broader utilization of existing ATE resources, 4) engagement of successful ATE PIs as mentors, and 5) an 8-year, longitudinal study of this mentoring system. In addition to serving as a model for leadership development and knowledge transfer adaptable for use within community colleges and for other NSF programs, the project will evaluate and disseminate its findings to broad audiences, and in so doing, provide resources to guide prospective grantees, and effectively engage two-year colleges and STEM faculty who are underrepresented geographically and demographically in the ATE Program, as they develop future talent for STEM technician education across the US.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mentor-Connect: Leadership Development and Outreach for ATE-2

(Mentor-Connect-2)

DUE #1501183 ? OUTCOMES REPORT

 

The Mentor-Connect-2 project has made grant funding from the National Science Foundation a more accessible and attainable opportunity for two-year college faculty members. NSF support for a previous Mentor-Connect project (DUE #1204463) established a system to provide effective mentoring and technical assistance to two-year colleges that had little or no previous experience in seeking grant funding from the NSF Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program.  This project improved on the model, added support services, and expanded the impact of the ATE program on technician education programs.

 

Mentor-Connect leverages talent and experience within the ATE program to diversify and broaden the impact of NSF funding. Through Mentor-Connect-2 the number of new-to-ATE colleges benefiting from ATE resources and/or ATE grant funding increased through work with cohorts of two-year college educators and other mentoring services. In 2015 when the first phase of Mentor-Connect ended, the project had served 59 colleges from 24 states. Mentor-Connect-2 has added 126 colleges across the nation. As of June 2021 the Mentor-Connect program had served a total of 185 colleges from 41 states and 2 US Territories since 2012.

 

Mentor-Connect-2 successfully engaged and supported the involvement of new, diverse technician educators; developed STEM faculty leadership skills; and, facilitated knowledge transfer from more experienced ATE grantees known as principal investigators to those who are new to ATE. Throughout, Mentor-Connect has worked to build mentoring capacity for the ATE program, including pilot-testing (2016-17) and then implementing (2017 to present) a Mentor Fellows internship to prepare new mentors. Mentor Fellows internships have become integral to Mentor-Connect?s faculty leadership development work.

 

Mentor-Connect-2 Outcomes

 

During the current project, Mentor-Connect personnel have updated and added to the previously established, curated collection of technical resources. These resources are available online in a searchable digital database that is designed to support mentors, mentees, and other individuals who are seeking NSF ATE grant funding.

 

Mentor-Connect also continuously leverages and expands the use of available resources developed by ATE centers and projects, NSF, and the American Association of Community Colleges (AACC). AACC, an active Mentor-Connect partner, broadly disseminates Mentor-Connect information to its national membership.  

 

To date, Mentor-Connect has received 274 applications and selected STEM faculty teams from 185 unique two-year colleges. Of those who were selected for cohort mentoring, 88% successfully submitted ATE grant proposals and 70% received ATE funding awards in the Small Grants for Institutions New to ATE track. These ATE project awards, of up to $300,000 each, infused two-year technician education programs with funding to implement a broad range of improvements.  

 

Qualitative evidence collected for Mentor-Connect-2 indicates that the grant-writing skills and knowledge gained through Mentor-Connect has contributed to the success of mentee faculty and their colleges? pursuit of NSF funding. Following their participation in Mentor-Connect, mentee colleges have applied for and received additional NSF awards as well as grant awards from other federal agencies and other entities.

 

Services Added during Mentor-Connect-2

 

The Mentor-Connect-2 project added support for prospective grantees as they navigated the NSF funding process. This increased the success of 12 or more prospective grantees through this portion of the NSF funding process each year.

 

The Mentor-Connect-2 project also began offering one-on-one consultations to colleges that applied for Mentor-Connect cohort mentoring, but were not selected. Many colleges acted on the mentoring advice provided. They strengthened their project ideas to better align with expectations of the ATE program, and either reapplied to Mentor-Connect for a future cohort, applied to another mentoring initiative for a better fit, or used the self-guided support available from Mentor-Connect?s online resources to prepare ATE proposals.

 

Conceived during the Mentor-Connect-2 project, the Mentor Fellows initiative within Mentor-Connect has come to fruition and has become a key aspect of the leadership regeneration mission of Mentor-Connect. Seventeen Mentor Fellows have completed internships, and 15 of these individuals have gone on to serve as Mentor-Connect Mentors.  Several who have completed Mentor Fellows internships also serve as mentors for other ATE-funded mentoring initiatives.

 

Summary

 

The Mentor-Connect-2 project brought to fruition a regenerative, technology-enhanced, peer-mentoring system for leadership development while broadening the impact of the ATE Program nationally.  During Mentor-Connect-2, the regenerative cycle of leadership development came full circle as the first educators working with Mentor-Connect secured an initial ATE award and then leveraged what they learned to secure subsequent ATE awards. Several Mentor-Connect mentees who became first-time ATE project principal investigators as Mentor-Connect participants have become Mentor Fellows and then Mentor-Connect Mentors.

 

The Mentor-Connect process for transferring knowledge from one generation of STEM education leaders to another is a model that is adaptable within community colleges and is now being used by several Hispanic-Serving Institutions and other NSF Division of Undergraduate Education programs.
